page.title: 19SITE OF THE BATTLE OF STOKE
page.content: The villagers of{East Stoke}are preparing to celebrate the 500th anniversary of the{Battle of Stoke } (or {Stoke Field)}with a week of celebrations in 1987. They held a medieval banquet in the summer of 1985 as a prelude to the main festivities. The site of the battle is thought to be on the Trent Hills between{Stoke} and{Elston.}A stone in the hedgerow of a field on the brow of the hill reads: HERE STOOD THE BURRAND BUSH PLANTED ON THE SPOT WHERE HENRY VII RAISED HIS STANDARD AFTER THE BATTLE OF STOKE 16th JUNE 1487 This marked the end of the{Wars of the {Roses.}The vast army raised by the pretender,{Lambert Simnel,}was driven down the hill towards{Fiskerton.}A local stream ran with blood, and has since been known as the{'Red Gutter', {'Red Dyke',}or{'Bloody Gutter'.
